awd_titl_txt: High-Precision Equations of State Through Standardized Sample Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
The composition, structure, and evolution of the Earth, planets in the Solar System and exoplanets, can only be examined in detail with precise models for the relationship between pressure, temperature, and density of planetary materials. This proposal will engineer microfabricated samples to create standardized samples that eliminate many of the complications that affect the precision and accuracy of such measurements. A key outcome of the work will be a "round robin" series of experiments at multiple laboratory facilities to assess the relative effects of sample quality, variations in experimental facility, and analysis method. As the proposed experimental approach will produce thousands of identical samples in each synthesis, the samples will be available to the broader experimental community for equation of state replication, phase diagram and diffusion studies, and measurement of electrical and thermal conductivity. This proposal will support the training for a PhD student and up to 3 undergraduate students. All data and conclusions will be published in the scientific literature and presented at academic conferences.	

The inference that the composition of the Earth's core is a mixture of iron, nickel and a small amount of lighter elements arises from the recognition that the Earth's core has a density lower than that expected for pure iron or iron-nickel alloys. However, inferring the abundance and identity of light elements is limited by the precision and accuracy of the thermoelastic properties of iron and iron-nickel alloys, as the impact of light elements is constrained through the discrepancy between the physical properties of iron-nickel alloys and that of the core. To assess the differences between thermoelastic properties under Earth's core conditions requires (1) accurate equations of state of the end member substances, and (2) a precise and accurate extrapolation of equations of state to core conditions. This proposal (1) will develop a strategy to assess the accuracy of equations of state at high pressures and temperatures by comparing the impact of different experimental approaches when measured to high precision, and (2) will quantify the uncertainty of extrapolated equations of state. These goals will be accomplished through the manufacture of custom and reproducible samples for use in the laser-heated diamond anvil cell focusing on the equations of state of hcp and fcc iron and iron-nickel alloys to high pressure and temperature. In the second stage of this proposal, measurements will be repeated at multiple synchrotron end station facilities that employ differing temperature measurement strategies.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
Accurate and precise measurements of the compression of materials under the extreme high-pressure and high-temperature conditions of a planet’s interior are critical for the modeling of the state and compositions of planets. Failure to account for small systematic errors lead to errors in the light element composition of the Earth’s core and lead to the misidentification of an exoplanet as a mini-Neptune instead of a super-Earth or vice versa.

This project addressed this problem by developing strategies to assess the accuracy of equations of state at high pressures and temperatures by comparing the impact of different experimental approaches when measured to high precision. Consistent Monte Carlo modeling of data, their uncertainties, and the co-variant uncertainties of the materials used to calibrate pressure may be used to derive an equation of state that relates sample density to pressure and temperature with greater accuracy, allowing for the cautious extrapolation to greater pressures and temperatures.

Intellectual Merit:

This project refit existing Pt, Ne, NaCl (B2), and Au data to permit for internally consistent pressure standards. This then allowed for the re-interpretation of two decades worth of published data on materials relevant to the Earth’s deep interior. In tandem, the results of this project demonstrate that thermal spectra measurements, used to measure the temperatures achieved in the laser-heated diamond anvil cell are quantitatively indistinguishable between two beamlines, HPCAT and GSECARS, for temperatures above 2000 K, but caution is needed in quantifying the precision and accuracy of temperatures below 1500 K due to differences in spectral range of the systems.

Drawing on the internally validated suite of pressure measurement and robust temperature measurements, the project determined equations of state and full covariance matrix of iron and post-perovskite. These models then allow for the extrapolation to lower mantle and core-relevant pressures and temperatures. Key results include determination that the Earth’s core has a 8 ± 2% density deficit relative to pure iron, requiring significant lighter elements be part of the core while placing concrete bounds on the uncertainty, a factor that is often neglected in such analyses (Martin el al., 2020 & 2021).

These results are applied and expanded upon to quantitatively assess the hypothesis of compositional coherence between stars and planets as implied by a condensation and accretion model for solar system formation. The large number of exoplanets now described in the Milky Way permit testing this hypothesis, yet require accurate and precise equations of state, often to pressures and temperatures well beyond the conditions under which data were acquired. Using these high-precision equations of state, to a suite of well-studied exoplanets finds support of compositional coherence with host stars (Schulze et al., 2021), and that super-Earths may be misdescribed as gas-bearing mini-Neptunes if using other equations of state (Unterborn et al., 2019). While most exoplanets follow a condensation and accretion model for solar system formation, this analysis identifies both “super-Mercury” planets with iron enrichment (Schulze et al., 2021; Martinez Rodriguez et al., 2022), as well as a distinct population of ocean worlds (Schulze et al., 2023).

Broader Impacts:

This project supported the two PhD students and three undergraduate students. Through this work, the PhD students participated in all parts of the project, developing skills in experimental work, data modeling, statistical methods, and written and oral communication skills. Both were supported in developing their professional skills as they pursued their chosen post-graduate fields.  Undergraduates participating in this project worked closely with the PI and graduate student mentors to learn experimental or computational techniques. Each was able to learn quantitative and communication skills that extend beyond their undergraduate curricula and offered an inside look at the research process. Two of the undergraduate students have moved onto PhD positions in their chosen fields.  

The interior modeling codes have been integrated into open-source software package, ExoPlex (Unterborn et al., 2022), allowing astronomers to use validated equations of state in exoplanet modeling, providing computational infrastructure to associated communities.
